contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “these” refers to the red, reddish-brown, and white horses that were behind the man who was among the myrtle trees. This could mean: (1) it is implicit that there were other men who were riding the horses, and that these phrases refer to the riders or (2) the horses are personified as being able to speak like people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: These are those

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implicit that Yahweh sent these out to walk about in order to patrol the earth. This does not suggest that they were wandering or lost. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to roam throughout the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “they” refers to the red, reddish-brown, and white horses that were behind the man who was among the myrtle trees. This could mean: (1) it is implicit that there were other men who were riding the horses, and that these phrases refer to the riders or (2) the horses are personified as being able to speak like people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: They answered & they said

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the nations that are at ease made the disaster worse.” This means that although Yahweh used these nations to punish Jerusalem, they did more harm to Jerusalem than what Yahweh had intended for them to do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they made the disaster worse

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to builders using their instruments to rebuild the city. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “builders will stretch out their measuring lines over Jerusalem” or “the people will rebuild Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the measuring line will be stretched out over Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “will sit in the open country” translates a word that refers to a city that has no walls. There will be so many inhabitants in the city that it will be too large to have walls around it. Alternate translation: “Jerusalem will not have walls around it … beasts within the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will sit in the open country & beasts within her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “touches” refers to a touch meant to harm. Alternate translation: “for whoever harms you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for whoever touches you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his holy place” refers to heaven, and not to the temple in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “from his holy place in heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from out of his holy place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to other priests who would serve in the temple under the leadership of Joshua. Alternate translation: “the other priests who live with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: your companions who live with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the “vine” and the “fig tree” are symbols of prosperity. This phrase describes actions in which people live prosperously and in peace. Alternate translation: “because they will be at peace, each person will invite his neighbor to come and sit under his vine and his fig tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: each man will invite his neighbor to sit under his vine and under his fig tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since there is no verb in this phrase, it may be necessary in your language to supply one. Alternate translation: “You will not succeed by might nor by power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Not by might nor by power

contextId.occurrenceNote: The top stone is the last stone placed when building something. This refers to the top stone of the temple. Alternate translation: “he will bring out the top stone of the temple” or “he will complete the construction of the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will bring out the top stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the word “grace” refers to God’s grace and the people are requesting that God bless the completed temple. Alternate translation: “while people shout, ‘May God bless it! May God bless it!’” or (2) the word “grace” refers to beauty and the people are declaring how beautiful the completed temple is. Alternate translation: “while people shout, ‘Beautiful! It is beautiful!’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to shouts of ‘Grace! Grace to it!’

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the time of small things.” This phrase refers to the time when the people were building the temple and appeared to be making little progress. Alternate translation: “the time when progress was slow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of small things

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implicit that the horses were pulling the chariots. Alternate translation: “The first chariot had red horses pulling it” or “Red horses were pulling the first chariot” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The first chariot had red horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the Israelites who remain in Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: those who are far off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that the Jews mourned during a part of the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar because in this month the remaining Jews in Jerusalem fled to Egypt after the murder of Gedaliah, whom the king of Babylon appointed as governor over Judah. The seventh month is during the last part of September and the first part of October on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]])
contextId.quoteString: in the seventh month

contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that the people of Israel had been slaves in Babylon for 70 years. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: for these seventy years

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that this anger is against the enemies of Zion. Alternate translation: “with great anger against her enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: with great anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that this refers to Mount Zion, the location upon which the city of Jerusalem was built. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the mountain of Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: People having the opportunity to grow old implies the city will be peaceful and prosperous for a long time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in his hand because he has grown so old

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the people are in exile. “I am about to rescue my people of Judah who went into exile” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to rescue my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: “in the past.” The implied information is that this refers to the time when the people started rebuilding the temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in former days

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that this is the remnant of the people who returned from exile. Alternate translation: “the people who returned from exile” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the remnant of this people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the way Yahweh had allowed the temple to be destroyed and his people to be exiled had been used by other nations as an example of what it meant to be cursed by Yahweh. Alternate translation: “When I punished you, the other nations learned what happens when I curse a people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You were an example to the other nations of a curse

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the implied information is that the people of Judah and Israel would be a blessing to the nations around them. Alternate translation: “you will be a blessing to the surrounding nations” or (2) the implied information is that the nations around them would see what it meant to be blessed by Yahweh. Alternate translation: when I bless you, the other nations will learn what happens when I bless a people” or (3) Yahweh will bless the people of Judah and Israel. Alternate translation: “I will give you many good things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be a blessing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that this refers to the places where judgment took place. Alternate translation: “in your places of judgment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in your gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that the Jews mourned during a part of the fourth month of the Hebrew calendar because this is when the Babylonians broke through the walls of Jerusalem. The fourth month is during the last part of June and the first part of July on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]])
contextId.quoteString: The fasts of the fourth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: The assumed knowledge is that the Jews mourned during a part of the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar because this is when the Babylonians began their siege against Jerusalem. The tenth month is during the last part of December and the first part of January on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]])
contextId.quoteString: the tenth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that Jerusalem is where the people will come. Alternate translation: “People will come again to Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: People will come again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that the foreigners will grab their robe to get their attention. Alternate translation: “will grasp the hem of your robe to get your attention” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will grasp the hem of your robe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The implied information is that people of God are going to Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “Let us go to Jerusalem with you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Let us go with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The references to “chariot” and “bow” means that this refers to horses used in battle. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “the warhorses in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the horse from Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they know these dreams are false. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “diviners lie about their dreams in order to deceive people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they tell deceitful dreams

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that those watching knew Yahweh was giving them a message through the breaking of the staff. Alternate translation: “knew that Yahweh had given them a message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: knew that Yahweh had spoken

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that this was very little pay for the shepherd. Alternate translation: “only thirty pieces of silver” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: thirty pieces of silver

contextId.occurrenceNote: A soldier would use his right eye to look around the shield that he held with his left hand. If his right eye was wounded, he would not be able to see to fight in war. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: his right eye

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that these are false prophecies. Alternate translation: “to prophesy falsely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to prophesy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies false prophets. Alternate translation: “every false prophet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: each prophet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Prophets often wore heavy outer garments made of animal hair. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: no longer wear a hairy cloak

contextId.occurrenceNote: “How did you get those cuts on your chest?” This refers to the apparent custom of false prophets wounding themselves in their ceremonies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: What are these wounds between your arms?

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that his answer is a lie. Alternate translation: “he will lie to him saying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will answer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “You will” refers to the people of Jerusalem. But, “you fled” refers to their ancestors since this describes an event that happened many years earlier. Alternate translation: “You will flee just as your ancestors fled” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You will flee just as you fled

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that there will be no light from the sun. Alternate translation: “there will be no light from the sun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: there will be no light

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that this is the land of Judah. Alternate translation: “All the land of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: All the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably refers to the place where wine was made for the royal family. It was located in the southwest part of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the king’s winepresses

contextId.occurrenceNote: These basins were used for boiling meat in the courtyard of the temple. Alternate translation: “the cooking pots in the courtyard of the temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the basins in Yahweh’s house

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the basins will be sacred like the bowls used for catching the blood of the sacrifices. Alternate translation: “will be as sacred as the bowls used at the altar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will be like the bowls before the altar

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was the custom for traders to sell the people things they needed in order to make proper sacrifices to Yahweh in the temple. Alternate translation: “people will no longer buy or sell things in the courtyard of the temple of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: traders will no longer be in the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “9.2 meters long and 4.6 meters wide” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: twenty cubits long and ten cubits wide

contextId.occurrenceNote: An “ephah” is a unit of measurement for dry materials and is equal to 22 liters. Here the word is a metonym for the container that would hold an ephah of dry material. Alternate translation: “This is a measuring basket that is coming” or “This is a large container that is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: This is a basket containing an ephah that is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the eighth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of October and the first part of November on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the eighth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Shebat” is the eleventh month of the Hebrew calendar. The twenty-fourth day is near the middle of February on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month, which is the month of Shebat

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Kislev” is the ninth month of the Hebrew calendar. The fourth day of Kislev is near the end of November on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kislev (which was the ninth month)

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Berechiah & Iddo

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Berechiah & Iddo

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Heldai, Tobijah, and Jedaiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a man. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jehozadak

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sharezer and Regem-Melek

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hadad Rimmon may have been the place where the good King Josiah died of battle wounds after the Battle of Megiddo. It appears that the custom arose to hold periodic mourning there for his death. Some people, however, think that Hadad Rimmon was the name of a false god who was believed to die every year, an event for which his worshipers would go into mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the laments in Jerusalem will be like the laments at Hadad Rimmon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a plain in Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Megiddo

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town or village east of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Azel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a plain in the Jordan River Valley. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Arabah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town on the northern border of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Geba

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a town south of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Rimmon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of gates in the northeast part of city wall of Jerusalem. This could mean: (1) “the first gate” and “the Corner Gate” refer to the same gate or (2) “the first gate” and “the Corner gate” are separate gates. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the Benjamin Gate & the first gate & the Corner Gate

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a strong point in the city defenses on the northern wall. It was probably built by a man named Hananel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the Tower of Hananel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Raising one’s hand against another person is a gesture of hostility. Here it is a symbolic action that means that God will attack those who harm Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “I myself will fight against them” or “I myself will attack them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself will shake my hand over them

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In 11:4-17 is a story about two shepherds. This could mean: (1) Zechariah actually became a shepherd over a flock as a symbolic act showing how Yahweh will treat his people or (2) Zechariah tells a parable that teaches how Yahweh will treat his people. Since it is uncertain which of these meanings is correct, it would be best not to specify either option in the translation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: a kind of small tree with colorful flowers (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: myrtle trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Horns were often used as a symbol for military power. Here they symbolize the powerful nations that had conquered the kingdoms of Israel. The words “Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem” represent the people who lived in those places. Alternate translation: “These horns represent the nations that have scattered the people of Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: These are the horns that have scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this vision “filthy garments” are symbolic of sinfulness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: Joshua was dressed in filthy garments

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here fine clothing symbolizes righteousness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: dress you in fine clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The seven lamps symbolize the eyes of Yahweh, but they are not literally the eyes of Yahweh. The angel speaks of Yahweh seeing everything that happens on the earth as if his eyes roamed over the whole earth. Alternate translation: “These seven lamps represent the eyes of Yahweh, who sees everything that happens on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: These seven lamps are the eyes of Yahweh that roam over the whole earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The branches symbolize these people, but they are not literally the people. Alternate translation: “These two branches represent the sons of fresh olive oil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: These are the sons of fresh olive oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The basket symbolizes the people’s iniquity, but it is not literally their iniquity. Alternate translation: “This basket represents the iniquity of the people throughout the whole land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: This is their iniquity in the whole land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The woman represents wickedness. Alternate translation: “This woman represents wickedness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: This is Wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chariots symbolize the four winds of heaven, but they are not literally the four winds. Alternate translation: “These chariots represent the four winds of heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: These are the four winds of heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) they may be symbolic language that refers to the Messiah who will come from the tribe of Judah or (2) they may refer to different leaders who will come from Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: the cornerstone & the tent peg & the war bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exclamation, and not a question. Alternate translation: “They will be very good and beautiful!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclamations]])
contextId.quoteString: How good and how beautiful they will be!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This angel is a new participant who has not appeared before this verse. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-participants]])
contextId.quoteString: another angel went out to meet him

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Zechariah often wrote prophecy in the form of poetry. Hebrew poetry uses different kinds of parallelism. Here Yahweh begins speaking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-poetry]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases are both ways to refer to Yahweh’s message that the prophets had declared to their ancestors. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my words and my decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ways” and “actions” mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “our behavior” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: our ways and actions

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words express urgency and add emphasis to the following command. The words can be translated with an expression that communicates urgency in your language. Alternate translation: “Run! Run!” or “Hurry! Hurry!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Up! Up!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) that the words “might” and “power” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of Zerubbabel’s strength or (2) that the word “might” refers to military strength and the word “power” refers to Zerubbabel’s physical ability. Alternate translation: “Certainly not by your own strength” or “Not by military strength nor by your own power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Not by might nor by power

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and refer to one animal. The second phrase clarifies that this is a young donkey. Alternate translation: “on a young donkey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: on a donkey, on the colt of a donkey

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “sea to sea” and “from the River to the ends of the earth” mean the same thing and can be combined. Alternate translation: “his kingdom will be over all the earth!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: his dominion will be from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ellipsis in this phrase may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “the left side of the bowl” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the left side

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ellipsis can be supplied from the previous verse. Alternate translation: “They are taking the basket to the land of Shinar to build a temple for it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: To build a temple in the land of Shinar for it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “month” can be supplied in translation. Alternate translation: “in the fifth month” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fifth

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that the “son” has died. Alternate translation: “for an only son who has died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: for an only son

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh exaggerates to emphasize how rich Tyre was. Alternate translation: “accumulated silver and gold as much as soil in the streets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: heaped up silver like dust and refined gold like mud in the streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “every nation” is a generalization that means “many nations.” Alternate translation: “I will cause many nations to attack Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: I will gather every nation against Jerusalem for battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave a message” or “Yawheh spoke this message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “at ease” means that the people thought that they lived in peace and security. Alternate translation: “I am very angry with the nations that enjoy peace and security” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am very angry with the nations that are at ease

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since Joshua’s garments were symbolic of his sinfulness, by removing his garments, the angel removed Joshua’s iniquity. Causing iniquity to pass from him is an idiom that means that he had removed Joshua’s iniquity. Alternate translation: “I have removed your iniquity from you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I have caused your iniquity to pass from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “to go and come among” is an idiom that means that Joshua will be a part of this group and have the same privilege as they do of access to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to come before me as these who stand here do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to go and come among these who stand before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave a message to me. He said” or “Yahweh spoke this message to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The word of Yahweh came to me, saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that these men have been anointed with fresh olive oil. A person who is anointed is one whom Yahweh has chosen or appointed for a special duty. Alternate translation: “the anointed men” or “the men whom Yahweh has appointed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the sons of fresh olive oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “stand before” means to be in a person’s presence and to serve him. Alternate translation: “who serve the Lord” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who stand before the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the surface of the whole land” refers to every place within the land. It is implied that the curse will apply to every person who lives in the land. Alternate translation: “that is upon every person within the whole land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: that goes out over the surface of the whole land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that they were flying. Alternate translation: “they were flying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: wind was in their wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave a message to me. He said” or “Yahweh spoke this message to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came to me, saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave a message to Zechariah” or “Yahweh spoke this message to Zechariah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came to Zechariah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh of hosts gave me a message. He said” or “Yahweh of hosts spoke this message to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh of hosts came to me, saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is used to introduce a special message from God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh gave a message to Zechariah. He said” or “Yahweh spoke this message to Zechariah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The word of Yahweh came to Zechariah, saying

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to be courageous for the work. Alternate translation: “Be strong and courageous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Strengthen your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to be courageous for the work. Alternate translation: “be strong and courageous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: let your hands be strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cut off” is an idiom that means to stop their pride. Alternate translation: “I will make the Philistines to be proud of themselves no longer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cut off the pride of the Philistines

contextId.occurrenceNote: To trample them into the mud is an idiom that means to completely defeat them. Alternate translation: “who defeat their enemies completely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who trample their enemies into the mud of the streets in battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “with them” is an idiom that means he is present to help them. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh is with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “strike” the waves is an idiom that means he will stop the waves from forming. Stopping the afflictions of his people is spoken of as calming the waves of that sea. Alternate translation: “I will cause the waves of that sea of affliction to stop” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will strike the waves of that sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “set in place” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “I am about to appoint a shepherd in the land” or “I am about to put a shepherd in charge in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to set in place a shepherd in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “come against” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “strike and wound his right arm and pierce his right eye” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: come against his arm and his right eye

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “so that they no longer think about the idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will no longer be remembered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “turn my hand against” means to act hostile towards someone. Alternate translation: “I will attack the lowly ones” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn my hand against the lowly ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “in the days” is an idiom that refers to the time when Uzziah was king. Alternate translation: “when Uzziah was king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the days of Uzziah, king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This normally means running or flowing water, rather than still or stagnant water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: living waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are idioms that refer to being hostile towards another person. Alternate translation: “Each person will grab someone, and they will fight each other” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Each one will seize the hand of another, and the hand of one will be raised up against the hand of another

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “came against” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “that attacked Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: that came against Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the people are wise for looking at Yahweh for help or (2) Zechariah did not really mean that the people of Hamath were wise and was using irony. Alternate translation: “though they think they are very wise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: for they are very wise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses irony to say that this price was very small for a shepherd doing Yahweh’s work. Alternate translation: “the ridiculously small amount of money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: the excellent price

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “earth” and “heaven” form a merism that refer to the sky. It is implicit that the two women flew away with the basket. Alternate translation: “They lifted the basket up into the sky and flew away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They lifted up the basket between earth and heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a poetic way of expressing specific countries to which the people were exiled. Alternate translation: “From the land to the east and from the land to the west” or (2) this is a merism that means from all directions. Alternate translation: “from all lands in every direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: from the land of the sunrise and from the land of the setting sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: This merism refers to all of life’s activities everywhere that anyone went. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: for anyone going or coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “right” and “left” represent every direction. Alternate translation: “in every direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: on their right and on their left

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of having a change of attitude toward another person as if it were turning or returning. The people turning to Yahweh means that they will again be devoted to him and worship him, while Yahweh returning to the people means that he will again bless them and help them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Turn to me & and I will return to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: No longer doing certain actions is spoken of as if it were turning away from those actions. The phrases “evil ways” and “wicked practices” mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “Stop doing all of your wicked actions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Turn from your evil ways and wicked practices

contextId.occurrenceNote: There being peace and quiet in the world is spoken of as if the earth were a person who is still and resting. This could mean: (1) this is a good thing that means that there is peace between nations or (2) this is a bad thing that means that there is no war because nations are helpless to fight against a stronger nation that has subdued them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: all the earth sits still and is at rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) although Yahweh had left Jerusalem when the people had gone into exile, he will now return to Jerusalem when they have come back from exile or (2) Yahweh speaks of having a change of attitude towards the people of Jerusalem and again blessing them and helping them as if he were returning to the city. Alternate translation: “I will once again show mercy towards Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have returned to Jerusalem with mercies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nations oppressing the people of Judah severely is spoken of as if no person in Judah was able to raise his head. Alternate translation: “and caused them to suffer greatly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: so that no man would lift up his head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the nations using their military power to conquer Judah as if the nations had lifted up their horns. He speaks of these four craftsmen destroying the military power of these nations as if the craftsmen threw those horns to the ground. Alternate translation: “to destroy the power of the nations who used their military might against the land of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to cast down the horns of the nations that lifted up a horn against the land of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: People built walls around their cities for protection. Here Yahweh speaks of protecting Jerusalem as if he himself were a wall of fire around the city. Alternate translation: “I … will protect the city, like a wall of fire around it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I & will become for her a wall of fire around her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “daughter of Babylon” refers to the city of Babylon. Yahweh speaks of the city as if it were a daughter. Alternate translation: “you who live in Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you who live with the daughter of Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Zion” is the same as “Jerusalem.” The prophet speaks of the city as if it is a daughter. This could mean: (1) Zechariah personifies the city as a person who can sing. Alternate translation: “Sing for joy, Zion” or (2) the phrase “daughter of Zion” is a metonym for the people who live in the city. Alternate translation: “Sing for joy, people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Sing for joy, daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zechariah speaks of the people of great nations becoming Yahweh’s people and worshiping him as if they were joining themselves to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “the people of great nations will become the people of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: great nations will join themselves to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zechariah speaks of Yahweh claiming Judah as his own land as if Judah were something that Yahweh inherits as a permanent possession. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will claim Judah as his rightful possession” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will inherit Judah as his rightful possession

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zechariah speaks of Yahweh beginning to act as if someone had roused Yahweh from inactivity. It is implied that this action refers to his returning to Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “he is coming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he has been roused

contextId.occurrenceNote: A brand is a burning piece of wood. The angel of Yahweh speaks of Joshua being rescued from captivity in Babylon as if he were a piece of wood that someone pulls from a fire before the wood is completely burned. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a brand pulled from the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Branch” refers to a messianic figure that would serve as king over Yahweh’s people. Yahweh speaks of this person as if he were a branch that grows out from a tree. Since the word “Branch” is a title, it should be translated with an equivalent word in your language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my servant the Branch

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sides or facets of the stone that reflect light are spoken of as if they are eyes. Alternate translation: “There are seven sides on this single stone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: There are seven eyes on this single stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor in which Yahweh speaks of the obstacles that Zerubbabel will face as if they were a large mountain. He asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that these obstacles pose no threat to Zerubbabel’s success. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You are nothing, great mountain! Zerubbabel will cause you to become a plain” or “Although obstacles may appear as large as mountains, Zerubbabel will overcome them as easily as one walks upon level ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What are you, great mountain? Before Zerubbabel you will become a plain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh removing these people from the land is spoken of as if he were cutting them off, like a person would cut a branch from a tree. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cut off every thief … Yahweh will cut off everyone who swears a false oath” or “Yahweh will remove every thief from the land … Yahweh will remove from the land everyone who swears a false oath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: every thief will be cut off & everyone who swears a false oath will be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The curse destroying the houses of the thief and of the one who swears falsely is spoken of as if the curse would consume the building materials that people had used to build the houses. Alternate translation: “destroy its wood and stones” or “completely destroy it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: consume its timber and stones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “grow up” refers to the growth of a plant, and so continues the metaphor of this person as a “Branch.” This likely refers to this person appearing or coming into power as the one who would supervise the rebuilding of the temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will grow up where he is

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an image of an ox refusing to allow its owner to put a yoke on its shoulders. This metaphor represents the people being stubborn. Alternate translation: “became stubborn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: set their shoulders stubbornly

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an image of people putting something into their ears so they would not hear the message from Yahweh. This metaphor represents the people not being willing to hear and obey. Alternate translation: “They refused to listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They stopped up their ears so they would not hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of how he will scatter the people as if a whirlwind were scattering everything in its path. Alternate translation: “I will scatter them as a whirlwind scatters things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will scatter them with a whirlwind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “If something does not appear to be possible to” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: If something seems impossible in the eyes of

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Alternate translation: “to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The earth and skies are spoken of as if they were persons giving what is needed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the earth will give its produce; the skies will give their dew

contextId.occurrenceNote: Those who want to know Yahweh and please him are spoken of as if they are literally seeking to find Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: seek Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is speaking about himself as if he were an army that was protecting his land. Alternate translation: “I will protect my land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will camp around my land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This dry pit represents the exile in Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the pit where there is no water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem is spoken of as a place of safety. Alternate translation: “Come back to your nation where you will be safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Return to the stronghold

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Judah are referred to as if they were a bow carried by God into battle. Here “Judah” refers to the people of that nation. Alternate translation: “I will cause the people of Judah to be like my bow” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have bent Judah as my bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel, the northern kingdom, as if they were arrows that he would shoot at his enemies. A quiver is a bag that holds a soldier’s arrows. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: filled my quiver with Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: To completely defeat enemies is spoken of as devouring them as a wild animal eats its prey. Alternate translation: “will completely defeat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were the expensive jewels in the crown of a king that show how glorious he is. Alternate translation: “They will be like beautiful stones in a crown” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They are the jewels of a crown

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the shepherds” represent the leaders of God’s people. The intensity of Yahweh’s anger is spoken of as if it was a blazing fire. Alternate translation: “My anger toward the shepherds of my people is as intense as a fire” or “I am very angry with the leaders of my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My wrath burns against the shepherds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Male goats are typically more dominant than female goats. Here “male goats” represents the oppressive leaders of God’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it is the male goats—the leaders—that I will punish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh changes the metaphor for his people from defenseless sheep to a mighty war horse. He speaks of his people as if they were a strong horse in battle. Alternate translation: “will cause them to be strong like war horses in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: make them like his warhorse in battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The cornerstone will come from Judah.” The most important ruler is spoken of as if he where the main foundation stone of a building. Alternate translation: “One of the descendants of Judah will become the most important ruler” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: From Judah will come the cornerstone

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the tent peg will come from him.” The tent pegs held the ropes that supported tents in which people lived. Here the most important ruler is spoken of as if he where the main peg that holds a tent in place. Alternate translation: “the leader who will hold the nation together will come from Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from him will come the tent peg

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the war bow will come from him.” Here the most important ruler is spoken of as if he where the a war bow that was used in battle. Alternate translation: “the military leader will come from Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from him will come the war bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people as a torn or dirty garment that Yahweh took off and threw away. This symbolizes rejection. Alternate translation: “I had not rejected them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: I had not cast them off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The exile of the people is spoken of as if they were seed that Yahweh had planted in a distant land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I sowed them among the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: Scripture often refers to the sea as an image of many troubles and hardships. Here Yahweh speaks of himself accompanying the people to help them go through these afflictions. Alternate translation: “I will go with them and help them as they go through their many afflictions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pass through the sea of their affliction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not resisting what is about to happen is spoken of as if Lebanon were opening its doors. Here “Lebanon” is a metonym that represents the people of Lebanon. Alternate translation: “People of Lebanon, get ready, because fire will devour” or “People of Lebanon, do not try to stop the fire that will devour” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Open your doors, Lebanon, that fire may devour

contextId.occurrenceNote: Fire completely burning up the cedars is spoken of as if the fire would devour the cedars. Alternate translation: “fire may completely destroy your cedars” or “fire may completely burn up your cedars” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: fire may devour your cedars

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor that speaks of the sky as if it were like a scroll that is rolled up and needs to be stretched out. Alternate translation: “the one who created the sky” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who stretched out the skies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor that speaks of the earth as if it were a building with a foundation. Alternate translation: “put all the earth into place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: laid the foundation of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh using Jerusalem to punish the surrounding peoples is spoken of as if Yahweh would make Jerusalem a cup full of an alcoholic drink that will cause the surrounding peoples to get drunk and stagger. Alternate translation: “Soon it will be like I make Jerusalem into a cup … to stagger about” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to make Jerusalem into a cup & to stagger about

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh using Jerusalem to punish the surrounding peoples is spoken of as if he would make Jerusalem a heavy stone. Alternate translation: “It will be like I will make Jerusalem a heavy stone for all the peoples” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make Jerusalem a heavy stone for all the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: Opening eyes over someone here is a metaphor for wanting to do good things for that person. Alternate translation: “I will do good things for the house of Judah” or “I will protect the house of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Over the house of Judah I will open my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Completely destroying the peoples is spoken of as if the people of Judah will “devour” them. Alternate translation: “will destroy the surrounding peoples” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will consume all the surrounding peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing the people to be compassionate and to plead is spoken of as if the spirit were a liquid that Yahweh would pour on them. Alternate translation: “I will cause the house of David and inhabitants of Jerusalem to have mercy on others and to pray to me for mercy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pour out a spirit of compassion and pleading on the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Forgiving the people’s sins is spoken of as if a spring of water will wash away their sins. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “it will be like a spring opens … to cleanse their sin and impurity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a spring will be opened & for their sin and impurity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing the people to no longer mention the names of idols is spoken of as if Yahweh would “cut off the names of the idols from the land.” Alternate translation: “I will cause the people to no longer mention the names of the idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cut off the names of the idols from the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophets may refer to “false prophets.” The spirit of impurity is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “I will also remove from the land the false prophets and their evil spirits” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will remove the prophets and the spirit of impurity from the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of a servant of Yahweh as if he were a shepherd. Alternate translation: “my servant who is like a shepherd” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of God are spoken of as if they were sheep. Alternate translation: “my people will run away like sheep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the flock will scatter

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being killed is spoken of as if they are cut off like cloth is cut from a garment or a branch is cut from a plant. Alternate translation: “that two out of every three people will die! Only one person out of three will remain in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-fraction]])
contextId.quoteString: that two-thirds of it will be cut off! Those people will perish; only one-third will remain there

contextId.occurrenceNote: Metal is passed through fire in order to purify or harden it. This expression serves here as a metaphor for exposing the people to suffering in order that they may become more faithful to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring that third through the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refining refers to making precious metals such as silver more pure. Metals such as silver and gold are tested in order to discover how pure or strong they are. Both refining and testing are here metaphors for making the people more faithful to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: refine them as silver is refined; I will test them as gold is tested

contextId.occurrenceNote: A future time is spoken of as if “a day is coming.” The phrase “will be divided” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Soon Yahweh will judge you, and he will allow your enemies to take all of your possessions and divide if for themselves while you watch” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: A day for Yahweh is coming when your plunder will be divided in your midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing people to suffer from a plague is spoken of as if the plague would attack the people like an army. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cause a plague among the people of the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A plague from Yahweh will attack the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “Jerusalem” and “cities” refer to the people who live in those cities. Alternate translation: “to the people of Jerusalem and to the people of the cities of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to Jerusalem and to the cities of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Jerusalem, and the word “house” is a metonym for the temple. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The people will build my temple in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: My house will be built within her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “my cities” refers to the cities of Judah and represents the people who live in those cities. Yahweh speaks of the inhabitants of those cities again being prosperous as if goodness were a liquid that overflowed the cities, which are its containers. Alternate translation: “My cities will once again be prosperous” or “The people in the cities of Judah will once again be prosperous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My cities will once again overflow with goodness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “Zion” refers to the people who live in the city. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will again comfort the people in Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will again comfort Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “house” is a metonym for the temple, while the word “courts” refers to the courtyards around the temple. Together the phrases mean that Joshua will have authority over the whole temple complex. Alternate translation: “you will have authority over my temple and its courtyards” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will govern my house and guard my courts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “land” represents the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “I will remove the sin of the people from this land in one day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will remove the sin from this land in one day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” represents the temple. Alternate translation: “the foundation of this temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the foundation of this house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “this” refers to the scroll. The scroll is a metonym for what is written on the scroll. Alternate translation: “On this scroll is the curse” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: This is the curse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the horses represent the chariots that they pull. Alternate translation: “the chariot with the white horses is … the chariot with the spotted gray horses is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the white horses are & the spotted gray horses are

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “my spirit” refer to Yahweh, so many translations change this to read “Yahweh’s spirit.” This could mean: (1) the word “spirit” represents Yahweh’s emotions and appeasing his spirit means that the chariots will cause Yahweh no longer to be angry with the north country Alternate translation: “they will calm my anger concerning the north country” or (2) the word “spirit” represents Yahweh’s presence and the chariots will cause the Jews who live in the north land to experience Yahweh’s blessings. Alternate translation: “they will cause my spirit to rest in the north country” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will appease my spirit concerning the north country

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “listen” means to obey and the word “voice” represents the words that Yahweh speaks. Alternate translation: “truly obey what Yahweh your God says” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: truly listen to the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” is a metonym for Yahweh’s presence. Alternate translation: “in the presence of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: before the face of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mouth” is a metonym for the words spoken by the mouth. Alternate translation: “by the words of the former prophets” or “through the former prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the mouth of the former prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the thoughts of a person. Alternate translation: “you must not make plans to do evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: let none of you plot any harm against another in your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “mouth of the prophets” is a metonym for the words that the prophets speak. Alternate translation: “through the words of the prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by the mouth of the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Zion” represents the people of Zion. Alternate translation: “for the people of Zion” or “for the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the people in the kingdoms of Judah and Israel. Alternate translation: “people of Judah and Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Judah and house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the people in the kingdom of Judah. Alternate translation: “people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Judah and house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the people in the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people in the other city. Alternate translation: “will go to the people of another city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will go to another city

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people in the mighty nations. Alternate translation: “people of mighty nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: mighty nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Hadrak” and “Damascus” refer to the people who live in those places. Alternate translation: “the people of the land of Hadrak and the city Damascus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of Hadrak and Damascus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” refers to what they look at. Alternate translation: “all humanity and all the tribes of Israel look toward Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the eyes of all humanity and all the tribes of Israel are toward Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live in that land. Alternate translation: “the people of the land of Hamath” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Hamath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live in those cities. Alternate translation: “the people of Tyre and Sidon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Tyre and Sidon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Tyre’s “strength on the sea” refers to the ships that were used for commerce and conquest. Alternate translation: “destroy Tyre’s ships in which men fight on the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: destroy her strength on the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: These cities each refer to the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “The people of Ashkelon … the people of Gaza … the hopes of the people of Ekron” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ashkelon & Gaza & Ekron, her hopes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” is a metonym for meat with blood in it, and “abominations” is a metonym for meat offered to idols. Alternate translation: “I will no longer allow them to eat meat that still has blood in it, and I will forbid them to eat food that they offered to idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will remove their blood from their mouths and their abominations from between their teeth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my own eyes” represent Yahweh’s personal attention. Alternate translation: “I will personally watch over my land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I see with my own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the action of announcing peace represents the action of making peace. Alternate translation: “for your king will bring peace to the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for he will speak peace to the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is speaking to the people of two different nations at the same time. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have roused your sons, Zion, against your sons, Greece

contextId.occurrenceNote: Slings to throw stones were a common weapon in the days of Zechariah. Here the “stones of the slings” represent the soldiers who were using them to attack Israel. Alternate translation: “defeat the enemies who attack them with slings and stones” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: defeat the stones of the slings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the people of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Alternate translation: “Judah” or “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here shame accompanies and represents defeat. Alternate translation: “they will defeat their enemies who ride warhorses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will shame those who ride warhorses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Alternate translation: “Judah” or “the kingdom of Judah” or “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “Israel” or “the kingdom of Israel” or “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the majesty of Assyria” probably refers to the Assyrian army. Alternate translation: “I will destroy Assyria’s proud army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The majesty of Assyria will be brought down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the scepter of Egypt” refers to the political power of Egypt. Alternate translation: “the power of Egypt to rule other nations will end” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the scepter of Egypt will go away from the Egyptians

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “their glory” probably represents the rich pastures that the shepherds led their sheep to. Alternate translation: “for their rich pastures are ruined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for their glory has been destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the pride” probably represents the forests that grew near the Jordan River. Alternate translation: “because the trees and shrubbery where they lived by the Jordan River are ruined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for the pride of the Jordan River has been devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “allow the people to harm each other and the king will oppress them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: turn over every person into the hand of his neighbor and into the hand of his king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “I will not save them from those who are harming them” or “I will not rescue them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: none of them will I deliver them from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” represents the people of the southern kingdom and “Israel” represents the people of the northern kingdom. Alternate translation: “between the people of Judah and the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: between Judah and Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents enemies who will attack the shepherd. Alternate translation: “May enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: May the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” represents the power to fight. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “cup” represents the cup and the contents within the cup. Alternate translation: “into a cup full of wine” or “into a cup full of an alcoholic drink” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into a cup

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents people. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hearts” represents a person’s mind. Alternate translation: “think to themselves” or “say to themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: say in their hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “The people of Jerusalem will again live in their own city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will again live in her own place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “tents” represents homes, and homes represent the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the tents of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the descendants of David or (2) the ruling class of people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents descendants. Alternate translation: “the descendants of David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents all the people living in the land of Judah. Alternate translation: “All the people in the land of Judah will mourn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The land will mourn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents descendants. Alternate translation: “The descendants of David … The descendants of Nathan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The clan of the house of David & The clan of the house of Nathan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents descendants. Alternate translation: “The descendants of Levi” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The clan of the house of Levi

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents descendants. Alternate translation: “the descendants of David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Speaking in the name of someone means speaking with his power and authority, or as his representative. Alternate translation: “you claim to speak for Yahweh but you speak lies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you speak lies in the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “They will call out to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will call on my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation or character. Alternate translation: “people will know that Yahweh is the only true God” or “people will only worship Yahweh, the one true God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there will be Yahweh, the one God, and his name alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people. Alternate translation: “The people will live safely in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will live in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Judah” and “Jerusalem” represent the people that live there. Alternate translation: “Even the other people in Judah will fight against the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah will also fight against Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Yahweh speaks of obeying him as if the person were walking along Yahweh’s paths. Alternate translation: “If you will obey me and keep my commandments” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
