contextId.quoteString: If you will walk in my ways, and if you will keep my commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences mean the same thing and intensify the command to rejoice. Yahweh is speaking to the people of Jerusalem as if they were present, but they were not there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Shout with great joy, daughter of Zion! Shout with happiness, daughter of Jerusalem!

contextId.occurrenceNote: This sentence uses a parallel structure to express that everyone will have plenty to eat and drink. If your readers might think that only the men ate and only the women drank, you may want to adjust the wording. Alternate translation: “All of the people, both men and women, will have plenty of grain to eat and sweet wine to drink!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The young men will flourish on grain and the virgins on sweet wine!

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel and together represent the entire population of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The young men & the virgins

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel and together represent all of the different kinds of the food and drink. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: grain & sweet wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the city of Tyre is pictured as a woman. Alternate translation: “built a strong fortress” or “built a high wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: built herself a stronghold

contextId.occurrenceNote: Cypress trees are spoken of as if they could grieve like a human. Alternate translation: “If the trees were people, they would cry out in sorrow. The cypress trees stand alone because the cedars have burned and fallen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Lament, cypress trees, for the cedar trees have fallen

contextId.occurrenceNote: The oaks of Bash are spoken of as if they could grieve like a human. Alternate translation: “If the oak trees in Bashan were people, they would wail, for their thick forests are gone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Lament, you oaks of Bashan, for the strong forest has gone down.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “her” refers to the city of Jerusalem. It was common in Hebrew to speak of a city or country as if it were a woman. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: surrounding her

contextId.occurrenceNote: “You, sword! Go and attack my shepherd.” Here Yahweh speaks to a sword as if it were a person. Here it represents enemies. Alternate translation: “You, enemies! Go and attack my shepherd” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Sword! Rouse yourself against my shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two rhetorical questions emphasize that both their ancestors and the prophets who proclaimed Yahweh’s message to their ancestors have died. The questions can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: “Neither your fathers nor the prophets are here because they have all died.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Your fathers, where are they? Where are the prophets, are they here forever?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question emphasizes the positive answer that it anticipates. Yahweh speaks of the people’s ancestors experiencing the consequences of not obeying Yahweh’s commands as if his words and decrees were a person who had chased after and overtaken them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “But my words and my decrees that I commanded my servants the prophets have overtaken your fathers.” or “But your fathers have suffered the consequences for disobeying my words and my decrees that I commanded my servants the prophets to tell them.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: But my words and my decrees that I commanded my servants the prophets, have they not overtaken your fathers?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel of Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the positive answer that it anticipates. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Joshua is a brand pulled from the fire.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is this not a brand pulled from the fire?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that Zechariah should have known what these things mean. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Surely you know what these things mean.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you not know what these things mean?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zechariah uses this rhetorical question to speak specifically about those who have “despised the day of small things.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Those who have despised the day of small things will rejoice” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has despised the day of small things? These people will rejoice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that Zechariah should have known what these things mean. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Surely you know what these are.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you not know what these are?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is asked to make the people think about what their real reason for fasting had been. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “you were not really fasting for me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: were you truly fasting for me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is used to make the people think about whether they were honoring Yahweh when they ate and drank. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “it was for yourselves that you ate and drank.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: did you not eat and drink for yourselves?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “These are the same words … to the west.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Were these not the same words & to the west?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zechariah compares the way in which the angel interrupted his being in deep thought with the way someone would awaken another person from sleep. Alternate translation: “caused me to become more alert like a man awakened from his sleep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: roused me like a man roused from his sleep

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people refusing to hear and obey Yahweh are compared to their being as unyielding as rock. Here the heart represents the will of a person. Alternate translation: “They stubbornly refused to hear the law or the words of Yahweh of hosts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They made their hearts as hard as rock so they would not hear the law or the words of Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites sometimes thought of lightning bolts as arrows that God shot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: his arrows will shoot out like lightning!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Judah will shout and celebrate their victory over their enemies as if they were noisy drunks. Alternate translation: “Then they will shout and celebrate their victory as loudly as if they were drunk” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Then they will drink and shout like men drunk on wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably refers to the bowls that the priests used to carry animal’s blood to the altar. Alternate translation: “they will be as full of wine as the basins with which priests carry blood to the altar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they will be filled with wine like bowls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Altars had projecting corners that were drenched in animal blood. Alternate translation: “they will be drenched as the corners of the altar are covered in blood” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: like the corners of the altar

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they are God’s sheep that he cares for and protects. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: God will rescue them & as the flock of his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people who do not have true prophets who tell the truth are spoken of as sheep who do not have a shepherd to tell them where to go. Alternate translation: “the people who listen to the false prophets are like sheep who do not know which way to go” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they wander like sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people who do not have true prophets are spoken of as sheep who suffer because they do not have a shepherd to tell them where to go. Alternate translation: “the people who listen to the false prophets … are suffering like sheep who do not have a shepherd to guide them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they & suffer because there is no shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: The rulers from Judah are spoken of as if they were victorious warriors. Alternate translation: “They will be mighty in battle, trampling their enemies into the mud of the streets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They will be like warriors & streets in battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Ephraim” refers here to the northern kingdom of Israel. Warriors are strong. Alternate translation: “Ephraim will be very strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephraim will be like a warrior

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means Yahweh will enable the leaders of Judah to be strong and able to lead the people to defeat their enemies. Alternate translation: “like firepots among stacked firewood … unharvested stalks of grain standing in a field” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like firepots among wood & standing grain

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means those who are weak will be strong. Alternate translation: “those who are weak will be strong like David” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: those who are weak among them will be like David

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “eyes” represents the person who looks. Alternate translation: “I looked up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I lifted up my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “eyes” represents the person who looks. Alternate translation: “I looked up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I lifted up my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “flesh” represents all humanity. Alternate translation: “all people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: all flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents Zerubbabel. Alternate translation: “Zerubbabel has laid … he will bring it to completion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The hands of Zerubbabel have laid & his hands will bring it to completion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “eyes” represents the person who looks. Alternate translation: “looked up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: lifted my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “eyes” represents the person who looks. Alternate translation: “Look up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Raise your eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eyes” represents the person who sees. Alternate translation: “I looked up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I lifted my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “eyes” represents the person who sees. Alternate translation: “looked up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: lifted my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the bow represents all weapons used in warfare. Alternate translation: “all weapons of war will be destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the bow will be cut off from battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hearts” refers to the whole person. They will have the same joy as a person who is enjoying drinking wine. Alternate translation: “and they will be very happy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their hearts will rejoice as with wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “feet” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “he will stand on the Mount of Olives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: his feet will stand on the Mount of Olives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what Yahweh of hosts has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh of hosts, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: this is the declaration of Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “justice,” “faithfulness,” and “mercy” can be stated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “When you judge, be just, faithful to the covenant, and merciful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Judge with true justice, covenant faithfulness, and mercy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be rewritten to remove the abstract nouns “truth” and “righteousness.” Alternate translation: “I will be their God. I will be faithful to them and act toward them in a just manner” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will be their God in truth and in righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **truth**, you can express the same idea with an adjective such as “true.” Alternate translation: “Everyone must say only true things to his neighbor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Speak truth, every person with his neighbor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be restated to remove the abstract nouns “truth,” “justice,” and “peace.” Alternate translation: “When you are making decisions in your gates, judge in a way that is true and just and causes people to live peacefully with each other” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Judge with truth, justice, and peace in your gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “joy” and “gladness” can be translated using adjectives. Alternate translation: “joyful and glad times, with happy festivals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: times of joy, gladness, and happy festivals

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abstract nouns “truth” and “peace” can be translated using adjectives. Alternate translation: “love what is truthful and peaceful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: love truth and peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **strength**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “strong” or “encourage.” Alternate translation: “make us strong” or “encourage us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: are our strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **fear**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “terrified.” Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cause the people to be very terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: that great fear from Yahweh will come among them

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: someone lifted a lead covering off the basket” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a lead covering was lifted off the basket

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “they will set the basket there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the basket will be set there

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “You will give the crown” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The crown will given

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “the people will safely sow seed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: seeds of peace will be sown

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and enemies will burn the city to the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: so she will be devoured by fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The majestic cedar trees are no more” or “The cedar trees were once majestic, but now they are ruined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: What was majestic has been devastated

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “no one punishes them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: are not punished

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the sheep that are perishing—let them perish” or “the sheep that are to wander and get lost—let them get lost” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the sheep that are being destroyed—let them be destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the covenant ended” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the covenant was broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “your enemies will capture the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the city will be captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Enemies will plunder the houses and rape the women” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The houses will be plundered and the women raped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not removing people from the city is spoken of as if the people will not be “cut off.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “your enemies will allow the remaining people to stay in the city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the remainder of the people will not be cut off from the city

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The presences of Yahweh will split the Mount of Olives … causing there to be a very great valley” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The Mount of Olives will be split & by a very great valley

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “only Yahweh knows when that day will begin” or “only Yahweh knows when that time will begin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a day known only to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “who bore him” describes “his father and mother” in order to express surprise that someone’s own parents would treat him in this way. Alternate translation: “his own father and mother” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-distinguish]])
contextId.quoteString: his father and mother who bore him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “myself” is used to emphasize that it is Yahweh who will do these things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: so you will know

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you will flee

dublin_core.title: unfoldingWord® Translation Notes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “30 pieces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: thirty pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the second year of the reign of Darius the king” or “the second year since Darius became king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the second year of Darius’ reign

contextId.occurrenceNote: “on day 4” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: on the fourth day

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Should I mourn in month 5.” The assumed knowledge is that the Jewish people fasted during a part of the fifth month of the Hebrew calendar because this is when the Babylonians destroyed the temple in Jerusalem. The fifth month is during the last part of July and the first part of August on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]])
contextId.quoteString: Should I mourn in the fifth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “in months 5 and 7” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the fifth and in the seventh month

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The fasts of months 4, 5, 7, and 10” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: The fasts of the fourth month, the fifth month, the seventh month, and the tenth month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This contrasts Jerusalem, which will remain at a higher elevation, to the surrounding area, which is lower in elevation. The contrast can be indicated by adding the word “but.” This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “But, Jerusalem will remain high up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/grammar-connect-words-phrases]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will continue to be raised up
